title:
Demonstration of Hardware Efficient Photonic Variational Quantum
  Algorithm
authors:
Iris Agresti and Koushik Paul and Peter Schiansky and Simon Steiner
  and Zhengao Yin and Ciro Pentangelo and Simone Piacentini and Andrea Crespi
  and Yue Ban and Francesco Ceccarelli and Roberto Osellame and Xi Chen and
  Philip Walther
abstract:
Quantum computing has brought a paradigm change in computer science, where
non-classical technologies have promised to outperform their classical
counterpart. Such an advantage was only demonstrated for tasks without
practical applications, still out of reach for the state-of-art quantum
technologies. In this context, a promising strategy to find practical use of
quantum computers is to exploit hybrid quantum-classical models, where a
quantum device estimates a hard-to-compute quantity, while a classical
optimizer trains the parameters of the model. In this work, we demonstrate that
single photons and linear optical networks are sufficient for implementing
Variational Quantum Algorithms, when the problem specification, or ansatz, is
tailored to this specific platform. We show this by a proof-of-principle
demonstration of a variational approach to tackle an instance of a
factorization task, whose solution is encoded in the ground state of a suitable
Hamiltonian. This work which combines Variational Quantum Algorithms with
hardware efficient ansatzes for linear-optics networks showcases a promising
pathway towards practical applications for photonic quantum platforms.
